<topcClas>Social indicators and quality of life - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Equality and inequality - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>         <topcClas>Use and provision of specific social services - Social welfare policy and systems</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>English and Welsh Civil and Social Justice Panel Survey</i> (CSJPS) collects data relating to people's experiences of civil justice (or <i>'justiciable'</i>) problems and the strategies they used to resolve them. <br> <br> The survey is a substantial development of the <i> English and Welsh Civil and Social Justice Survey</i> (CSJS), which was first conducted in 2001, then again in 2004, and on a continuous basis between 2006 and 2009. Respondents to the first wave of the CSJPS, conducted between June and October 2010, were asked about the experience of problems in each of 15 distinct civil justice problem categories: consumer; employment; neighbours; owned housing; rented housing; money; debt; welfare benefits; divorce; problems ancillary to relationship breakdown; domestic violence; education; care proceedings; personal injury, and clinical negligence. <br> <br> For up to three problems (selected at random, if more than three problems had been experienced), respondents were asked about disputants, problem resolution strategies, advisers consulted, formal dispute resolution processes, how and when problems concluded, the causes and consequences of problems, understanding of rights, and regrets. For one (random) problem, respondents were also asked for detailed information about the steps they had taken to resolve it. <br> <br> Extensive Demographic and household details were also collected. The fieldwork for the second wave of the CSJPS was carried from winter 2011 (18 months after the Wave 1). The survey was broadly similar to Wave 1. Ongoing problems at the time of the wave 1 interview were also revisited at wave 2, with further details set out in the technical report and questionnaire.</abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The main topic of the study is the public's exposure and response to the experience of civil justice problems.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd event="start" date="2009-01-01T00:00:00Z">January 2009</timePrd>         <timePrd event="end" date="2012-05-01T00:00:00Z">May 2012</timePrd>         <timePrd>Interviews sought experience of civil justice problems for the 18 months prior to the interview.</timePrd>         <collDate event="start" date="2010-06-01T00:00:00Z">June 2010</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2012-05-01T00:00:00Z">May 2012</collDate>         <collDate>Wave One: from June 2010 to October 2010; Wave Two: from November 2011 to May 2012</collDate>         <nation>England and Wales</nation>         <geogUnit>Government Office Regions</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Districts (Metropolitan)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Districts (Non-metropolitan)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Unitary Authorities (England)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>London Boroughs</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Unitary Authorities (Wales)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Postcode (District)</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Families/households</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit>Other units: problems.</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>All adult respondents in sampled households across 194 postcode sectors of England and Wales.</universe>         <dataKind>Textual data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Alpha/numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Longitudinal/panel/cohort</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Wave One was cross-sectional. Wave Two used the sample of respondents from Wave One for longitudinal study and new individuals to reach the overall sample size of around 4,000 interviews.</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Ipsos MORI</dataCollector>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <sampProc>Wave One: the sample design was based on a two-stage equal-probability sample of addresses, with interviews attempted with all adults at each address.<br>Wave Two: included both longitudinal (interviewed at Wave One) and freshly sampled individuals in order to maintain the overall sample size at 4,000 interviews (this latter sample was drawn using the same sampling methodology as in Wave One).</sampProc>         <deviat>3,806 adults in Wave One and 3,911 adults in Wave Two</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>For weighting details, please see documentation files.</weight>         <cleanOps>B</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Available to all registered users for any use</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required. Available to all registered users. The depositor may be informed about usage.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relPubl><b>For Wave One of the survey: </b><br> <br> Plesence P., Balmer, N., Patel, A., Cleary, A., Huskinson, T., and Cotton, T. (2011) <i>Civil Justice in England and Wales: Report of Wave 1 of the English and Welsh Civil and Social Justice Panel Survey</i>.
